characters: AND SLIPS INTO A DRUNKEN SLUMBER.
FOR ALL HIS HARD WORK... P.S. 247 CHRISTMAS PAGENT 1932
SITCOM ON TV, (INTERCUT WITH ANNE'S APT.)
WE FADE OUT OF THE SCENE ON THE NEXT LINES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP ON RADIO/ALARM CLOCK reads 5:59 a.m.  The digital numbers flip to 6:00 and the RADIO goes on:  a talk show host speaks in a soft, soothing voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's six a.m.... Ooooooo and that bed never felt sooooo gooood... Mmmm, you linger in a warm, gentle dream state... ever so comfortable... ever so safe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But suddenly you realize it's Monday! A woman SCREAMS... the D.J., JACK, speaks at a rapid fire pace... a HAND from O.S. tries to shut the alarm off in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... your hand races to shut off the alarm before your mind wakes up... SCREAMS... the HAND knocks over a water glass and grabs the clock but can't find the off switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But it's too late!  If you don't get out of bed now, you'll never have enough time to blow dry your hair that special way... You'll never make that nine o'clock meeting that your partner will be early for... You will be late and everyone will notice! The HAND bangs the clock violently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Rumors will fly about you losing your edge... Someone will casually mention they saw you downing shots of tequila at the Xmas party and before you know it, you're spilling your guys to a Senate committee or selling yourself on street corners to middle aged men from the Midwest... Headlines flash across your mind -- "Sleeping Investment Banker Guns D.J. Then Self -- Claimed -- 'I only wanted two more minutes!'" SCREAMS... SILENCE... The D.J. (Jack) speaks in a normal voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hey, it's Monday morning, and I'm Jack Lucas. The HAND rips the clock off the night table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN in a bathrobe spoons the contents of a protein drink called Executive Protein Blast into blender...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I don't have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes, you do because you see, today, you're our...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotlight Celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked man shaves as he listens to the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in the spirit of fairness, we want the public to hear your side of things.  So, now... how long were you and Senator Peyton having this sleazy affair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am tired of the public thinking they've got the right to invade a person's private life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman sensually applying lipstick and makeup as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please!... You had sex with a United States Senator in the parking lot of Sea World... You're telling me you're a private kind of person. No... you're our...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotlight Celebrity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's still all anybody talks about. Nobody even thinks to ask whether we loved each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hordes of business people stampeding towards their jobs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because nobody cares about that, sweetheart.  Nobody wants to hear about your romantic love.  No.  We want to hear about the back seats of limos... the ruined lives of people we want to be... new and exotic uses for champagne corks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People line up to buy coffee and danish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I have been humiliated enough already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps not -- We need those details... The Woman hangs up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escalators packed with people move like conveyor belts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Jack Lucas and we're discussing personal pet peeves.  Go ahead, caller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... well... It's my husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CENTRAL
dialogues.text: Hundreds of people moving like ants in every direction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives me crazy.  I'll be talking and he'll never let me finish a sentence... He's always finishing my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlaps) -- Finishing your thoughts.  That's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midtown traffic.  Angry cab drivers yelling at pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  It absolutely drives me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) -- Drives you crazy, huh?  The scoundrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Jack.  It's Edwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Edwin!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "HAPPY DAYS ARE HERE AGAIN" plays then is abruptly stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Edwin.  We haven't heard from you in what -- a day?... I've missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Edwin on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVERHEAD SHOT of radio host as he speaks, while he manipulates tapes, dials, switches, etc... at a breakneck speed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've missed you too, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: SFX
dialogues.text: Edwin laughs, perhaps a bit over zealously -- He is a simple minded soul... a lonely child in the body of a lonely man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Edwin, baby, this is Sunrise Confession time... what have you got for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I... went to this bar... this very, ya know -- hard-to-get-in place... called Babbitt's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HANDS of the radio host pushing buttons, bending a paperclip out of shape...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know the place.  It's one of those chic yuppie gathering holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simple minded laughter) Okay... I know but... I met this beautiful girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Host's HANDS pop in a tape  "WEDDING BELLS," then a NEEDLE scratching it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Edwin, if you start telling me you're in love again, I'm going to have to remind you of the time we made you propose to that check-out girl at Thrifty's that you liked so much.  Remember her reaction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another TAPE, another button pressed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "Mister Big Stuff... Huh... Tell me... Who do you think you are... Mister Big Stuff... you're never gonna get my love..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) I wasn't serious about her, Jack. That was just a joke for you guys... She was just a girl.  This is a beautiful woman.  She wears pearls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA KEEPS MOVING about the studio and the host, but we never see his face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but does she swallow, Edwin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she likes me... she gave me her number, but she must work a lot cause when I call she's never home... But I think we'll go out this weekend... I've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Edwin, sure... and Pinnochio is a true story... Edwin!  Wake up! This is a fairytale...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew perform their duties with little enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jack, no, it's not... She likes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gave you the old brusheroo, kiddo... Believe me -- this tart will never make it to your desert plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) She likes me.  She said for me to call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) "What a fool believes... He sees..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the song) Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwin... Edwin... Edwin... I told you about these people.  They only mate with their own kind.  It's called Yuppie-In-Breeding... that's why so many of them are retarded and wear the same clothes.  They're not human. They can't feel love.  They can only negotiate love moments.  They're evil, Edwin.  They're repulsed by imperfection and horrified by the banal -- everything America stands for.  Edwin, they have to be stopped before it's too late.  It's us or them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slight pause, as EDWIN considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious) Okay, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: END CREDITS.
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS from a wall clock as JACK LUCAS winds up his broadcast:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, folks... It's been a thrill, as always. (false sincerity) "Have a perfect day"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PAN several studio technicians making ready for the end of the broadcast to the talk show host Jack Lucas -- handsome, aggressive, intelligent -- an underground media star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone here on the Jack Lucas Morning Show says "bye".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jack Lucas... So long... arriverderch... I'll be sure to send you a thought today as I lie in the backseat of my stretch limo, have sex with the teenager of my choice... And that thought will be:  Thank God I'm me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack motions to techy behind glass.  Then leans back in his chair, as a RADIO COMMERCIAL begins. His expression seems grave -- not one you would expect after a successful broadcast.  He appears tired and annoyed.  He sighs in relief that it is over.  The studio team work around him in silence -- with no indication of the relationship they have "on air."  Jack pulls out a bottle of aspirins and takes two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; annoyed, to the room) I want you all to know I'm getting sick again and it's because someone keeps forgetting to raise the thermostat before I come in here... My fucking ass is freezing for the first hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A techy makes mocking faces behind his back.  Another techy suppresses a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of a script entitled: "On The Radio," a situation comedy by Alan Siegal. LOU ROSEN, Jack's agent, who sits in the backseat beside Jack, thumbing through the script and chuckling to himself.  Jack stares in silence out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know some of this is very funny. Cheever told me they've even secured the rights to the Donna Summer song to play over the credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan indifference) Ooooo, I have chills... (deadpan interest) Are you sure they want me?  I won't read unless I have an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, of course... Not even a question.  When I spoke to him on the phone this morning, I could actually smell how much they want you for it. I could smell it over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street bum, half dressed, walks in between the stopped cars, banging on the windows and asking for money.  He BANGS on Jack's window.  Jack stares at him through the tinted glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; looking through his pockets) I don't think I have any change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamant) I am not opening this window. (looks at the bum) A couple of quarters isn't going to make any difference anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bum looks at the reflection of himself in the mirrored window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expansive Tribeca loft.  The modern, minimalist decor gives it a sleek, cold feeling.  A space full of glass, angles and edges, with no place to feel safe and sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mirrored door closes revealing Jack's reflection -- He takes a good look at his face in the mirror -- admirin every contour, every pore.  He mumbles as he's making coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate my cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's girlfriend, SONDRA -- an artist with a beautifully sculptured face and body -- sleek, cold, like Jack's apartment, she is eating a bowl of cereal, studying the cereal box.  Beside her is a sketchpad with an ink drawing of a stalk of wheat (similar to the cereal box) growing out of the belly button of a naked male-figure who's torso/pelvis is shaped like a map of America.  Jack enters, toweling his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask that when you clean your hands you wipe the ink off the inside of the sink before it stains the stainless steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) You can ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack has in his hand the television script entitled, "On The Radio."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raoul called before.  About dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack quickly opens his eyes.  Sondra crosses to the wall of closets and begins to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About dinner as a concept or about dinner with... (over-enunciating) Raoul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) You're so witty.  I'm so jealous... I need to get out of here, Jack, and do something other than sit in this apartment and count how many funny lines you have per page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, tomorrow's a very big day for me... It would be nice if you acted like you understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  I'll say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're putting me on film tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peeved) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply felt) ... First time in my life I'll be a voice with a body.  Do you know what that means?  What this could lead to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsnapping her bra in the front) Jack, it's a sitcom -- you're not defining Pi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll remember that the next time you get excited by drawing pubic hairs on raisin bran. (lighting joint and inhaling) Want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How un-sixties of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was nine in the sixties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to think my biography would be JACK LUCAS - THE FACE BEHIND THE VOICE, but now it can be JACK LUCAS, THE FACE "AND" THE VOICE...or maybe just JACK - EXCLAMATION POINT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SONDRA slips off her top as she climbs the stairs. JACK eyes her sexy back. Feeling sexy, he rises and follo INT. BATHROOM - NIGHT. SONDRA leans over and turns on the shower. JACK naked legs enters the bathroom behind her and closes the door.  CAMERA ON BATHROOM DOOR as we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unaffected) Jack, I have work to do too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK seduces SONDRA O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Can't we do this later?... (PAUSE) All right..well..If we do this now, can I have dinner with Raoul?

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM FLOOR
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS a brown paper bag, a plate of half-eaten Chin food, a bottle of beer into a bathtub where JACK languish in a bubble bath studying his script.  In the B.G. we hea Ella Fitzgerald singing, "I'VE GOT THE WORLD ON A STRING"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hey...for-...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False start. JACK clears his throat, pauses, then tries a (sarcastic...insincere...) "Hey! Forgiiiive ME!"

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alarm clock reads 11:15.  JACK is still rehearsing, while T.V. plays with no sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "  HEY! Forgive MEEE!" .... ...FOR-GIVE-ME ... Hey...forgive me! (HE smiles and shuts the script:) I have this...I really have this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE tosses the script aside and rubs his head. HE suddenly notices, on the soundless T.V., a picture of himself on a news broadcast.  Confused, he raises the volume with th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A news broadcast: a REPORTER in mid-report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...everything America stands for. Edwin, they have to be stopped before it's too late.... It's us or them."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Mr. Lucas's off-handed remark that seemed to have a fatal impact on Mr. Malnick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An after work hot spot, Babbitt's is popular with single young professionals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwin Malnick arrived at the peak hour of seven-fifteen, took one long look at the handsome collection of the city's best and brightest  - then removed a shotgun from his overcoat and opened fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S face turns white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be INTERCUT with JACK'S APARTMENT. The bar's glass has been blasted. Tables are overturned. Paramedics are running about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven people were killed before Mr. Malnick ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PICTURE OF EDWIN MALNICK is shown as the REPORTER conti ... turned the gun on himself and shot a hole through his head....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWIN MALNICK looked sad and harmless. JACK quickly grabs PHONE and RE-PLUGS it. HE is about to make a call when he stopped by the REPORTER mentioning his name... ...Representatives of radio cult personality Jack Lucas expressed regret, however no formal comment has been made. None of Babbitt's regulars had ever seen Edwin Malnick before....but tonight, few will soon forget this lonely man - who reached out to a world he knew only through the radio - looking for friendship...and finding only pain...and tragedy... This is Marc Saffron...Channel Ten news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is frozen.  His breathing grows heavy. HIS phone begins to ring. but JACK is unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS DOWN from the tall skyscrapers to the tiny video store that sits as if in a valley between two mountains.  PAN toward the store as we FOLLOW a customer through the door we SUPER:  A YEAR or so LATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS through variety of customers looking through the rentals, past the counter where employees are helping the clientele and into the:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing to a CLOSE UP of the headline of a sensation- alist tabloid -- "WOMAN KILLS PLASTIC SURGEON THEN SELF,

dialogues.speaker: TOLD FRIENDS
dialogues.text: The picture of a bug-eyed society woman is below the caption.  A hand comes out from behind the paper, reaching for a bottle of scotch on the table.  The bottle disappears behind the paper. ANNE, the owner of the store, enters abruptly -- closing the office door behind her, a cigarette dangling for her mouth.  Her desk is organized litter -- her walls are filled with porno tapes.  She searches for one as she talks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are insane today. They took insane pills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit about Anne as she searches for a video:  Anne is in her mid-to-late thirties... and she is all woman!  She has a raw, earthy, unmistakable sensuality.  Her red lipstick matches her red nail polish like a hat and glove set.  Inlaid on each nail is a rhinestone design of a little star.  Her angora sweaters are tight and clinging, giving her breasts a decided lift and perkiness.  Her backless pumps slap the ground.  A half-smoked cigarette hangs out of her mouth with great expertise -- a skill Anne obviously picked up in a high school bathroom.  Her voice is thick with a delicious Brooklyn twang. She is pure streetwise in attitude, philosophy and emotio She turns and speaks to the man behind the tabloid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey!  Mr. Happiness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man lowers the newspaper:  it is Jack Lucas: no longer the aggressive radio star but more -- a man who looks like he hasn't slept in months.  An intolerant, paranoid, self-pitying misanthrope.  The outrageous articles fascinate him.  Anne removes the paper and scotch bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are we going to work today or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stares back.  Anne waits for an answer.  Jack looks through the open office door and sees the store is packed with rush hour customers -- any one, a potential mass murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hello!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack jumps a bit then rises and crosses out the door cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's POV -- CAMERA MOVES "cautiously," taking in the crowd as they move about the walls of movies.  Suddenly, the giant face of a FRUMPY SECRETARY -- POPS INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JACK) Can you help me!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack subtly shudders at the surprise.  He stares deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... I'm at an absolute loss.  I've been looking for an hour -- I'm losing my mind. (overly dramatic, rambling on) ... I'm sort of in the mood for a Katharine Hepburny, Cary Granty kinda thing -- Nothing heavy... I couldn't take heavy.  Somethin' zany.  I need zany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stares at her, at a loss. SHE gets an inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...OH! OH! Do you have anything with that... comedian who's on that show? What's it - ON THAT RADIO!  Ya know,  the guy that says "HEY...FORGIVE ME...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK grins his teeth and stares like a madman while ANNE, aware of the affect this phrase has on him, throws a worr look from the cash register.  The FRUMPY SECRETARY laughs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get such a kick outta the way he says that...He's so adorable! Didn't he make a movie... I need something like that - a funny, no brainy kinda thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stares at the woman manically then turns to the shel movies behind the desk. Selecting one, he hands it to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great... (reading box aloud) "ORDINARY PEEPHOLES"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WOMAN'S eyes go wide. JACK stares at her deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of a - Big Titty- Spread Cheeky kinda thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE, who has heard this entire exchange, has to bite her lip to prevent herself from laughing...SHE pulls JACK awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry. (almost laughing) I need to borrow him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ANNE tugs at his sleeve, JACK eyes the WOMAN like a ma being lead away from his prey. INT. VIDEO POP OFFICE - DAY. ANNE stands before JACK who leans against her office door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in a mood today baby? Is this one of those days when you're in ...whadda call it... an emotional abyss?  Talk to me, cause I don't understand these moods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, they're MY moods. If you want to understand moods, have one of your own!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go upstairs... take the day off. All right?...I'll cook tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE kisses him, then exits. JACK is not comforted in the by this show of affection - especially when he notices he strap sticking out from her sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going for a specific look with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and Jack sit around a formica kitchen table in silence after eating dinner.  Anne smokes a cigarette.  A portable TV sits on a stand before them --

dialogues.speaker: SITCOM ON TV, (INTERCUT WITH ANNE'S APT.)
dialogues.text: We hear a STUDIO AUDIENCE LAUGHING on the TV... Anne herself can't help but laugh.  She snorts from trying to keep it in.  Jack shoots her a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's funny!  Whatta want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny.  It's... sophomoric and mindless... and dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why the hell do we watch all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in one breath) Because it makes me feel good to see how not funny it is and how America doesn't know the first thing about funny which makes it easier not being a famous funny TV celebrity because that would just mean that I'm not really talented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well forgiivvee meee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE and LAUGHTER... Anne just stares at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sick fuck... I don't know why you torture yourself. (she hits his head) Too many thoughts -- too crowded in there.  You should read a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her paperback and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important to think.  It's what separates us from lentils... and people who read books like... (reading her paperback cover) ... "Love's Flower Bed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up to get a drink from Anne's makeshift bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) It happens to be a beautiful love story. (hurt) Ya know, you used to like that about me.  You used to say you liked that I didn't make you think so much.  That we could be together and not think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... suicidal paranoiacs say funny things sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is deeply hurt by this.  She gathers her dignity and exits into the bedroom, slamming the door behind her. Jack downs his drink as the sitcom returns to the TV O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope when I'm your age you're finally dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fed up, Jack throws his coat on, storms out and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack exits into the rain, tearing his coat on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, depressed and wet, walks the streets of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands before his old building, looking at it longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wet Jack stops to watch the goings on at the entrance. He sees a limousine at the Plaza -- parked and awaiting its occupants.  A handsome man in his forties exits the hotel and walks toward the limo.  He is holding the hand of his six year old SON, who is carrying a two foot high plastic, smiling Pinnochio doll.  Both father and son are dressed in ties and jackets.  Jack watches in envy.  His ripped, wet clothes a shabby reflection of the man's.  He eyes the limo with longing.  As the man tips the doorman, a BUM approaches and asks for money.  When the man refuses and turns his back to enter the limp, the Bum becomes aggressive and starts pulling at the man's jacket and yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry fucking Christmas... Happy fucking New Year!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to harass the man, who pushes his son away. The doorman comes to the man's rescue.  As they both try to pull the Bum off the man, the six year old son notices Jack and walks calmly over. Jack, mesmerized by the scene, doesn't notice the Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks down.  The Boy stands directly before him. Jack sort of smiles.  The Boy extends his arms and offers the Pinnochio doll to Jack.  Jack is confused but the Boy simply deposits the doll into his arms and walks back to the limo.  By that time, the Bum is being held by the doorman, and both father and son enter the limo. Jack holds the doll.  He is surrounded by street people asleep or drunk on the sidewalk near the hotel.  He angrily realizes there's not much difference between him and them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody here named Jimeny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drunk groans.  Jack snaps the doll under his arm and walks O.S.

dialogues.speaker: STATUE NEAR PLAZA
dialogues.text: TIGHT SHOT of newspaper front page on sidewalk... Headlin reads:  "FIFTH HOMELESS MAN FOUND BURNED ALIVE"... CAMERA MOVES OUT to reveal that the paper is covering the head o a street person sleeping on the edge of the stone, flower dividers on Park Ave... CAMERA PANS OVER to a drunken Jac sitting on the sidewalk against the divider, having a conversation with Pinnochio beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever read any Nietzsche?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smiling Pinnochio clearly has not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Nieztsche says that there are two kinds of people in this world... People who are destined for greatness like... Walt Disney and... Hitler... and then there's the rest of us... He called us the Bungled and Botched. We get teased.  We sometimes get close to greatness but we never get there.  We're the expendable masses. We get pushed in front of trains... take poison aspirins... get gunned down in Dairy Queens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks from his Jack Daniels bottle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You wanna hear my new title for my biography, my little Italian friend... "It Was No Fucking Picnic - The Jack Lucas Story".  Like it?... Just nod yes or no... (tries it in Pig-Italian) "Il Nouva Esta Fuckin' Pinicko" -- (he smiles) You're a good kid... Just say no to drugs... (he nods and drinks) Ya ever get the feeling sometimes... you're being punished for your sins...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of two feet standing beneath the railing overlooking the East River.  Taped to one ankle is a brick.  Taped to the other is a brick around a smiling Pinnochio doll.  An empty bottle of liquor drops to the ground and shatters. Jack stands prepared to surrender his fate and make the final leap.  He stares at the river, almost smiling.  He has made his decision.  He is calm and serene.  He raises his foot over the railing. The headlights of a car drive INTO FRAME, illuminating Jack.  He turns to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two white upperclass JUEVENILE DELINQUENTS -- one wearing a leather jacket, the other a high school windbreaker -- get out of the car.  Each is carrying a gallon of gasoline.  Leather also carries a bat.  Jack is drunk but he is immediately aware of the danger when he spots the gasoline cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said what's going on? (walks up to Jack) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack shakes his head and before he knows it, Leather shoves the bat into his gut, sinking Jack to his knees. Windbreaker places the gasoline cans on the bench and begins to unscrew them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You shouldn't hang around this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clutching his stomach) I... I was just leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People spend a lot of hard earned money for this neighborhood.  It's not fair... looking out their windows to see your ass asleep on the  streets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I... I agree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (to Windbreaker) You believe this drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windbreaker shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) .....Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...No please...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINDBREAKER hands LEATHER the can, who raises it above JA head. AS THE GASOLINE SLOWLY LEAKS ONTO A PETRIFIED JACK FIGURE MOVING OUT FROM THE DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All hope abandon, ye who enter here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, THE YOUTHS TURN to the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the-....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ARROW with a rubber suction tip comes flying out of th dark and connects to WINDBREAKER's groin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIGURE stands backlit - mysterious and powerful, noble fearless. JACK, LEATHER and WINDBREAKER instinctually bon together in the face of this fourth unknown entity. The figure turns out to be a BUM. Grimy face, tattered la of clothing beneath a long over coat, a pork pie hat with twig sticking out of it like a plume in a helmet of yore. Over his shoulder, a homemade bow and arrow set. Although clearly downtrodden, behind his beaten appearanc radiates a calm intelligence and strength. There is somet distinctly attractive and confident about him. We learn l his name is PARRY; a combination of Don Quixote and Harpo PARRY  stands before them absolutely delighted with himse hand on hip - beaming with pride..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhand that degenerate - you adolescent ass of a one balled donkey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a bum...You know, there's enough in here for the two of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a la Glinda) Ha, ha, ha, ha rubbish...now begone...before somebody drops a house on you!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEATHER walks right up to PARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fag too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fag..a fag you say!?... "Curst wolf! Thy fury inward on thyself Pray and consume thee!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY notices a pimple on LEATHER'S cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo...that looks like it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE presses the zit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OWWW....What are you nuts?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BINGO! Tell the man what he's won!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINDBREAKER grabs PARRY, pinning his arms behind him. WINDBREAKER laughs. PARRY just turns his head and stares his eyes, causing WINDBREAKER to feel weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I advise you to let us go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You advise us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out numbered son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY glances over LEATHER's shoulder. LEATHER TURNS to s A BUM pushing a shopping cart comes out of the darkness. is mumbling to himself incoherently. Another BUM, appears the dark, unnerving WINDBREAKER. PARRY looks to a third BUM, stepping out of the dark, menacingly. Taken by themselves, the BUMS would look harmless and pat But in the context of their uncharacteristic organization THEY appear frightening. LEATHER and WINDBREAKER automatically whip out switchblad and take a "rumble" stance - as if protecting their catch, Jack. Jack sort of sides with them if for no other reason than - he's known them longer. LEATHER tries to remain confident. HE laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Go for it! What the hell are they gonna do? They can't do nothin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! They can do nothing! Gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY takes a few steps back and raises his hand. JACK stands close to LEATHER and WINDBREAKER, who prepare themselves for attack. PARRY lowers his hand which acts as a signal for the BUMS The BUMS reach into their coats and each pull out a FLASH which they shine at each other as THEY SING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like New York in June...How about you? I like a Gershwin tune...How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, LEATHER and WINDBREAKER are at a loss. The BUMS are getting all the words, but they're definitely in sync. PARRY lowers his hand proudly. The BUMS keep singing and their flashlights upon JACK, LEATHER and WINDBREAKER - bl them to PARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEATHER brandishes his knife towards the dark spot where thinks PARRY stands. But PARRY takes a flying step back. As he speaks, the Bums stop singing and hum the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son...There comes a time in every man's life...and you will learn this, if and when you become men...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his hat, PARRY pulls a long tube sock tied at the end and filled with a softball at the bottom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....That there are only three things in this world ya need...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE begins to swing the sock over his head - centrifugally gaining force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Respect for all kinds of life, ....the love of one other person who you can trust and pork on a regular basis ...and a nice navy blazer...Oh, and one more thing....always... keep your eye.... on the ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY releases the "weapon". The sock flies out of the darkness and, with amazing accuracy - beans LEATHER on the forehead between his eyes drops his knife to rub his head. HE sinks out of camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow...Ow....OW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINDBREAKER grows worried as PARRY reaches in to the lini of his coat, pulls out another "sock weapon" and starts s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, the ability to bean a shithead can be a fabulous advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WINDBREAKER runs to the car and drives away. PARRY crosses to a speechless JACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up LEATHER'S knife) Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneeling, rubbing his head) OWW...MAN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disoriented) Please don't hurt me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "OH beings blind! What ignorance besets you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY kneels down, pulls out some rope from his coat and to tie up LEATHER, who is disoriented and dazed. PARRY ha JACK LEATHER'S knife. Sickened by it, JACK flings it in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave me tied up out here alone, you fucking faggot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (PULLS DOWN LEATHERS PANTS, EXPOSING HIS BUTT) You won't be alone for long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY pulls out a triangle and begins ringing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a great place. (Raising his hand HE calls to BUM 1:) ...UH...WARREN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like New York in June...How about-....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) NO..GUYS...GUYS.... (to JACK) They're so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A violent explosion between warring factions of bums, who are defending territories and rights....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Parry sit facing the three Bums from the  previo scene - A Black, A middle-aged Irishman and an Ex-Hippy - and the Pinnochio Doll.  The Foursome sit against the gia base of the bridge discussing the issues of the day as th a bottle. OTHER BUM CLIQUES are scattered throughout the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There ain't no justice in life! There's just satisfaction. And the death penalty's just another violation of my constitutional right to satisfaction Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a lit cigarette hangs from his mouth) I hate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you mean if somebody like, killed your mother, you wouldn't want him dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I would. But I should get to kill him Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining further) He gets to kill him.  That's democracy, see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LULL takes over as they all consider this. JACK sitting the furthest apart from the group, looks lik in the middle of a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles to himself) This is it. I'm in hell. Damned to an eternity of idiotic conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans in and smiles) Great place huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Irishman lets out a bloodcurtling scream:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responds) AAAAHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK jumps. Irishman looks to PARRY & speaks in calm mono

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine John and you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IRISHMAN absent mindedly flicks his cigarette ashes o JACK'S SLEEVE, which is soaked with gasoline. The SLEEVE JACK panics - waving his is arm, trying to get it out. PARRY is both amazed and impressed - seeing it as a sign. The bums talk casually as JACK tries to rip off his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to IRISHMAN) So what do you think of the death penalty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death's definitely a penalty. Ain't no fucking gift.  Life's too goddamn short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the fire out, JACK tries to leave, saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better be going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrusting the bottle at him) Have a drink...don't be shy! (JACK sits quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This worries Jack. PARRY retrieves him and brings him bac to the group. The IRISHMAN removes the bottle from his saliva soaked mo hands it to JACK, who is disgusted:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no that's all-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRINK! GODDAMN IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK grabs the bottle and drinks - holding back his nause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would anyone like a fruit pie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you...Too sweet...to fattening...Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK feels sick as the cheap liquor running through him. IRISHMAN begins reciting a Chaucer passage in old English The BLACK stares off, half listening. PARRY turns to JACK his face beaming, he clasps his hands and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Et in arcadia ego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man...Why did God invent mediocrity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This remark acts like a slap in the face to JACK. The oth consider it in silence - not really knowing what it means The cheap liquor begins to take it's effect and from JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were phenominal tonight, Parry. (affirmations from the other two) SUPER-BUM, man! Fucking Marvel Comics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is asleep on a mattress beside a boiler spewing stea HE is slowly awakened by water dripping on his cheek - - - the first dull pangs of a mean hangover making itself k HE opens his eyes, confused -- not knowing exactly what happened.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIANT FACE OF PARRY
dialogues.text: lying parallel beside him -- like a kid waiting for his parents to wake up Xmas morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and cheery) How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarred, Jack nods suspiciously.  He notices the surroundings --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly) Hahahahaaa... Nononono... Not yet... Hahahaha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his head throbbing) If you're going to murder me, that's fine... just don't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to focus his eyes and looks around the room: there is an extremely organized "living area" -- a make- shift kitchen with hot plate, a nail in a wall with clothes on hangers... There is also a dumpster sitting beneath a garbage chute -- The dumpster has planets and stars painted on its side. Jack looks to the far wall and sees a handmade collage mural:  pictures cut out and pasted in a haphazard manner, all medieval in origin; grassy landscape with castles, knights and maidens on horses, crests and symbols of the Crusades, and various renditions of the Holy Grail... One maiden stands out from the rest -- a frail looking doe-like creature. On the adjacent wall, however, there are no pictures. Only frantic scribblings in red marker... Out of the scribblings we can see:  an evil looking face with a bear amateurishly drawn... a large red horse drawn as if it hurt to get out the image... the style is violent and erratic. Jack looks to the other wall and finds Parry's arsenal -- homemade "weapons" that also look medieval, like lances made from mop sticks, nets made of knotted rope, slingshots and a shield made from a garbage can cover with a rose painted on it.  Against each wall are piled, what seems to be hundreds of books.  Jack doesn't know what to make of all this.  He is frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My abode... My domicile... My neck of the woods... Hungry?  Breakfast?  A fruit pie perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... thanks... Listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizes he's barefoot) Hi... Where are my shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're -- (suddenly stands) -- What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumps) Where -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the air) What!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sshhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry looks like he's listening to someone.  Then he smiles broadly at Jack, which makes Jack worry even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to the air) I knew it!  I knew it last night! (beat; argues) I did too!  He's the one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels beside Jack, which makes Jack lean up against the boiler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you know what the Little People just told me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Little People?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said you're The One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands abruptly) Oh shut up!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a can of wintergreen air freshener and starts spraying, with violent strokes, to shut "them" up... Jack gets more nauseous from the smell... Parry yells to the air:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... I've got a right to say something.  I mean, you're tying my hands here! (to Jack) They say you're not ready to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not... (to himself) Now, where are those shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack makes a move to stand when Parry stops spraying and yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hheeyy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits back down.  Parry whispers to the air:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... You're frightening him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry kneels before him.  Jack presses against the boiler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh... I'm drawing a blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a guess... (shouts to the air) Let him guess!!  Tch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes for the air freshener but Jack's reply stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... gee... well... you seem to be some kind of vigilante...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... I mean that sort of happens along the way but no... (proudly) I'm on a very special quest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I need help and they sent you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clarifying) The Little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They work for Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans in to whisper) God... I'm the janitor of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's face drops.  Parry gets comfortable and explains casually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... They came to me about a year ago. I was sitting on the john having one of the most satisfying bowel movements -- you know the ones -- where you just see God... And I saw them... just floating around... hundreds of these... cute little fat people... And they spoke.  They said "I" was chosen to help them get back something very important they lost. But my part might be very dangerous. I said "Whoah".... slow down... ya start hearing voices from floating little fat people that tell you you're on a mission for God and you wind up in a mini-series.  Then they said "Look in Architecture Today, Feb '88... page 33..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry quickly crosses to a pile of magazines, grabs one and dives back to Jack, who keeps scanning for his shoes. Parry leafs through the magazine and opens to page 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) And there it was... plain as day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows Jack a feature about Langdon Carmichael, a Malcolm Forbes type real estate baron.  The five page pictorial depicts his ten million dollar restoration of an old N.Y. Armory into a palatial city home.  Caption reads:  "REAL ESTATE BILLIONAIRE LANGDON CARMICHAEL'S TOWER OF POWER"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Langdon Carmichael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmichael himself -- a dashing bachelor around fifty- five -- is shown standing in his private library beside a glass commode.  Parry points to inside the commode, where a golden chalice is displayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Grail... The Holy Grail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates the pictures on the collage.  Jack's losing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holy Grail?  Some billionaire has the Holy Grail sitting in a commode on Madison Avenue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know!  You can't imagine how surprised I was.  Who would think you could find anything divine on the Upper East Side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed now) Listen... I don't mean to be flippant or to enrage you or anything but... you're an imbecile.  And I'm not The One... I'm not any One...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry tries to speak but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think you're a very nice... very nice psychotic man.  I really appreciate what you did for me.  It was a very brave and noble thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please... you're embarrassing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I wish you all the luck in the world. When you get the Grail, I'm sure I'll be seeing lots of you on various talk shows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) But I can't get it... He's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs to the wall with the scribblings in red and indicates the evil face with the beard... He picks up a red marker and begins scribbling furiously -- adding to the face and the horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He's out there... I don't know if... He's always out there, see... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the marker and smiles to Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) See, you don't know him... That's why you're the one... You can get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, forget the shoes.  I'll just take a cab... Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry... I'm Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry rushes to a corner and gets Jack's shows and Pinnochio doll, then rushes to Jack and hands them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... You can keep the doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a mill -- (like a corporate exec) And I'll give you a buzz as soon as I hear from the people upstairs and we'll get this thing off the ground... Thanks for stopping by, Jack.  Give my love to the wife and kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry grabs Jack's hand and shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny -- you look married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified, Jack makes a hasty exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps out of what appears to be the entrance to the basement.  He walks down the hallway toward the front exit when suddenly an apartment door swings open.  FRANK, a burly black superintendent with a hearing aid, steps  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you comin' from?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... basement I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells to basement) I tell him no visitors!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's hangover sets off another explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraaaaankkk!  Who's at the door?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack glances through the half-opened door and sees the bottom half of Frank's wheelchair bound WIFE:  one leg is normal, the other is a pink prosthetic.  Both, however, are wearing furry mules.  Jack's nightmare doesn't seem to end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' to somebody.  Ya gotta yell like a banshee?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my manner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard of hearing) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it's just my manner!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's head is now nearly split down the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a friend of Parry's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... (trying to clear his vision) He is supposed to live there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... I let him stay there. What else could I do after such a tragedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tragedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dying to tell) He and his wife was were at some bar ..and some nut came in with a shotgun and blew the place apart. She was a beautiful girl...She never knew what hit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack goes numb. He can't believe his ears. HE leans against  the wall for support....CAMERA ON Jack as Frank continues O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ....You must have heard about it. That nut who listened to the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHT CHANGE on Jack against the bare wall. (Perhaps even the scenery is moved behind him) as we fade out Frank's v

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Parry's not his real name. His real name's Henry Sa....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - - And fade in Anne's voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..Listen. I understand about open relationships. Please. I was a teenager in the sixties after all....I understand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits at her desk, surrounded by her shelves of porno tapes. Jack sits before her looking like death warmed ove Frank's voice reverbs in his head as he half listens to A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....But when you care about somebody ya need more than an open relationship. Ya need a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her intercom RINGS. Anne's tone immediately changes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) WHAT!....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy wants to check out the pornos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So send him back! (she flicks off the intercom and returns to Jack, softly) ... Ya need to pick up the phone and tell me that you're not dead... that you haven't been attacked or raped or who knows.  You disappear last night. I don't know what to think.  I was up all night.  Look at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meek, fiftyish BUSINESSMAN has entered and begins to browse through the porno videos discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smell gas... Do you smell gas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and the Businessman exchange glances.  Jack is about to respond when Anne continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I can't tell you how distraught I was.  All night long.  What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two kids tried to set me on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God... What did they do!  My God!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to Jack and hugs him... The Businessman turns with a concerned look, having overheard.  Jack indicates to Anne that he feels awkward in front of the Businessman.  Anne confronts the Businessman with as little tact as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you almost done?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta looking for -- a story!? (makes a selection) Here... "Creamer Versus Creamer"... It won an award.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hides his face so as not to laugh.  Anne ushers the man out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You were attacked.  My God.  Should I call a doctor!  Did you call the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine... really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right... you sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nods.  So, Anne moves on to more important matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... So... where did you sleep last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I stayed at a friend's.  Listen, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts up her hand) Please... before you go on... let me tawk... okay... We've had a wonderful time together... When we first met, you said this wasn't serious and I shouldn't get serious and then you moved in and we haven't been serious. And I just wanna say that I have no regrets.  None.  And don't wanna have any now so I want ya to be up front with me... I want the truth. If you're seein' somebody else, let me know... You don't have to pour gasoline on yourself and light a match just to break up with me.  Just tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks to her -- somewhat admiring the bravery and integrity underneath the peasant stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not seeing anyone else.  I really was attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (satisfied, she struts to her desk) ... I love you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... You don't have to say it back... although it wouldn't kill you.  I'll cook tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and Jack have just finished eating dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what the Holy Grail is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne takes a long drag then puts it out in her leftover food.  Jack is repelled by the habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holy Grail?  Yeah... I know that. It was like -- Jesus' juice glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, I used to be such a Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure... Gotta believe in God. (trying to be  intellectual) But I don't think God made man in his own image.  No.  'Cause most of... the bullshit that happens, is because of men.  No, I think man was made out of the devil's image and women were created out of God -- because women can have babies which is sorta like creating, and which also explains why women are attracted to men, because, lets face it, the devil is a helluva lot more interesting -- I slept with a few saints and let me tell you... Booooorring!!!... And so the whole point of life, I think, is for men and women to get married so the devil and God can live together and, ya know -- work it out... (Anne moves to him and leans in for a kiss) ... Not that we have to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack notices a brown spot on her chin and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You have a little... uh... something on your face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I got a pimple... This stuff is supposed to blend with my skin color... Like it really works, ya know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack moves to the bar to fix a drink.  Anne follows him and takes the drink out of his hand.  Jack knows what this means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm up to it tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne massages his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a very traumatic experience... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne nods but keeps massaging.  As long as he wasn't with a woman, she doesn't care.  Her massaging gets more intense -- moving up his head and contorting his face as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think I'm getting sick... (trying to be forceful) I... I slept in a boiler room, Anne... I'm tired... I'm upset... I'm... just not in the mood!... Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne grabs his face with both hands and pulls him into a kiss.  She proceeds to climb onto his body as she utilizes a skill she picked up in high school make-out parties.  She is a pro.  Jack, against all his better judgement and will -- despite the pimple cream -- is rendered helpless by this woman's passion... He returns the embrace and guides her to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits in his underwear on the living room floor before an open closet with a cardboard box between his legs.  The box is filled with tapes of Jack's past radio shows.  He begins to sort through them... reading titles, remembering moments... then stops when he comes upon newspaper clippings of the murder at Babbitt's.  Edwin Malnick's face stares at him from a yellowed front page. The memories sour.  He moves to the bar.  Anne exits the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter, hon -- can't sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the radio tapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you something, Anne.  I really feel like I'm cursed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh stop.  Things will change.  My Aunt Mary always said, there's a remedy for everything in this world except death and having no class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get this feeling like I'm... a magnet but I attract shit.  Out of all the people in this city, why did I meet a man who's wife I killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't kill anybody.  Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was some way I could... just... pay the fine and go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne crosses to Jack and gently touches him.  Jack turns and clutches her to him tightly.  Lowering his head to hers, he cries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is alone in the basement.  He slowly walks around the room -- picking up little items here and there, as if trying to discover some clue to Parry.  He scans the titles of the piles of books.  All of them have something to do with medieval history or literature, myths, or the Crusades... He picks up one of the books and opens it... Page after page has been ripped out anywhere there might have been a picture or a diagram.  He comes upon a large scroll that he unravels.  It is a map, drawn by Parry, of Langdon Carmichael's house and the surrounding blocks... He rolls it up... The Pinnochio doll sits on a broken chair facing the wall with the nightmarish scribblings... acting like a sentinel. He crosses to the prominent picture of the maiden with the long hair.  He notices a small stand before the picture, with a candle.  It is like a shrine with offerings:  a flower, a small perfume sampler, a box of Jawbreakers candy and a dime store romance novel.  Jack doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... just looking for Parry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is drawn to the scribblings on the wall and makes out the faint shape of a man on a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say his name used to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP - duffel bag of Parry's things before Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hospital said it would be better if we kept certain things away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank speaks O.S. as Jack looks through the items:  ... a Master's degree in Medieval History... Another in Medieval Literature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... That's his real name -- Henry Sagan.  He was a teacher over at Columbia.  They kept him in some mental place on Staten Island... He did not speak for over a year then all of a sudden, he starts talkin' only now he's this Parry guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... A torn picture of Parry in a tux... his wedding ring... a thesis entitled THE FISHER KING, A MYTHIC JOURNEY FOR MODERN MAN... Frank continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... He used to live upstairs with his wife, so when he got released they sent him here.  I felt bad.  He couldn't work.  Nobody wanted him. So I let him stay in the basement. He helps out -- I give him a couple of dollars.  People throw things away he gets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack holds a beautiful photographic portrait of Parry's wife:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...She was a beautiful girl. He was crazy about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLACK, the IRISHMAN and the HIPPY are in their usual place. THEY lean against the wall, observing the afternoo life that walks by. JACK enters the scene and asks them w PARRY is. The HIPPY begins to speak and points to his rig JACK nods in appreciation and hands them a couple of doll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK approaches PARRY from across the street; he is sitti top of a car near a souvlaki vendor and eyeing A CLOCK TO across the street and to the left of the building. HE stu the time as he recites under his breath (we only hear exc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Soveriegn princess of his captive heart what dire affliction has thou made me suffer, thus banished from thy presence with reproach, and fettered by thy rigorous command, not to appear again before thy beautiful face. Deign princess, to remember this thy faithful slave, who now endures such misery for love of thee"....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY smiles casually and, without looking at Jack, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE then returns his gaze to the clock which is approachin JACK reaches in his pockets and pulls out some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Listen...I thought maybe you could use a-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CLOCK STRIKES NOON. PARRY grabs JACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COME ON!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE pulls JACK into the building. EXT. MET LIFE BUILDING - NOON. Several business men and women make their way out the elevators for lunch. PARRY and JACK position themselves with a clear view of the center elevator. The doors open and after several more aggressive co-workers exit, PARRY' DAMSEL in distress appears out of a revolving door, but quickly gets "revolved" back into the building....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be back....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Lydia makes an exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she a vision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REACTION SHOT OF A BEWILDERED JACK as he looks at LYDIA - a dowdy, waif-like sparrow of a thing -  makes he way through the lobby. SHE is torturously self-conscious, clumsy, formless and plain. She wears loose frocks that g her no shape and make her appear to be swimming in materi SHE wears no make-up; her unstyled hair is kept off her f by a single beret that keeps sliding down her head, and h contact lens are always dry, causing her to blink and use

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, gorgeous...Look, I'm going. I just wanted to give you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starts to dig in his pocket, but Parry is already off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the glass in interior, we can see LYDIA sitting by eating lunch. CAMERA PANS OUT TO THE STREET where PARRY and JACK are sitting on the hood of a car, watching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loves dumplings.  It's her Wednesday ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYDIA raises a dumpling to her lips with a pair of chopst SHE then accidentally drops it into a dish of soy sauce a splatters her dress.  Unnerved, she hastily wipes herself knocking over a glass of water when she removes the napki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she sweet. She does that every time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack squints at Lydia as if trying to see what Parry sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Parry have followed Lydia into a bookstore.  She stands browsing through a revolving bookstand.  They watch from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She buys a new book every two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia spins too hard, sending books flying off.  She replaces the books, but keeps one called "Loves Lusty Longings"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiles with great affection) She's into trash.  Whadda you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry and Jack are following Lydia, when she stops at a newsstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got a real sweet tooth.  If anybody ever told me I'd be in love with a woman who eats Jawbreakers, I'd said they were nuts. (reverentially) But look at that jaw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack doesn't want to look.  If the Little People made Parry seem crazy, this infatuation confirms him as beyond hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia buys some candy then turns and walks back toward her office building, once again waiting her turn to dive into the revolving doors.  She disappears into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you follow her every day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-huh. I'm deeply smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A businessman, walking in the opposite direction, throws candy wrapper on the street as he passes Jack and Parry. Parry suddenly stops, outraged, pulls out a slingshot and fires a stone at the man's head.  The businessman is hit but doesn't know how, since Parry grabs Jack's arm and resumes walking casually in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if every time someone did something offensive they hit in the head with a pebble, I think they might alter their behavior. What do you think Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Jack can respond, PARRY spots a rummage find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh look! A cooler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry spots an abandoned COOLER filled with junk and star going through it. Things are getting weird again, so JACK seizes the moment to accomplish his initial task - he pul out a fifty dollar bill and hands it to PARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here...I just would like to help you. I thought...maybe...you could use some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK digs deeper and hands him a twenty. PARRY is dumbfou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's another twenty. Will that do? (sorting through his change) I mean, what's it going to take!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No..no, it's..I don't know what to say. This is so nice of you...Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE hugs him on the street which embarasses JACK to no end

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away) That's O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take you to lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No..I have to get back to work. Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK walks away. CAMERA stays on JACK for a few yards unt turns around and sees: PARRY handing the money to a BUM in a doorway, yelling in an imaginary phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SELL!....SELL!....SELL! (HE takes the money from PARRY) BUY!...BUY!...BUY!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEY!!...HEY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK walks back to PARRY, who is explaining to the BUM, w now talking gibberish:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he understands) Well, I think you should be realistic. Ya can't start an ad agency on fifty dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? (to BUM) Give that back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bum screams in defiance... PARRY pulls JACK away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I gave it to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what am I gonna do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I gave it to you...to help YOU...not him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, then smiles mischieviously) You really want to help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wary JACK, who's afraid to reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the Upper East Side, PARRY and JACK stand across the tree-lined street from the ten million dollar armory/hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty impressive huh?...Don't let it scare you. I'll admit it's formidable but everything has it's weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just break into Langdon Carmichael's house. This man has done nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K...let me explain this one more time...The Holly Grail is in -....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Listen - please...don't start drooling or...rolling your eyes when I tell you this but - You shouldn't do this..There is no Holy Grail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
