dialogues.text: Of course there is, Jack. What do you think the Crusades were - a frat initiation? I don't think so...There has to be a Grail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you're only sort of insane, really. People like you can lead semi-normal lives. You could get a job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a job. I have a quest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it back - you're fucking deranged... And you're going to get yourself killed trying to get in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch. You are so sweet...Now I know why you're saying this. ...You're afraid I'm in danger and you're trying to protect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think you're a moron and I don't want to get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring this, PARRY gets filled with emotion and hugs JA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You are such a great guy. First the money, now this. (to the LITTLE PEOPLE) Isn't he fabulous!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away) Please don't hug me in public again, O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) I LOVE THIS MAN...YA HEAR ME JADED CITY... (JACK is mortified) ...I'M DAFFY ABOUT THIS GUY AND I DON'T CARE WHO KNOWS IT!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An COUPLE pass by, obviously not wanting to know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut-up!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a true friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. Believe me. I'm scum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real honest to goodness good guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm self-centered, I'm weak - I don't have the will power of a fly on shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why the Little People sent you. Just like magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in little floating people! THERE IS NO MAGIC!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? You going to help me?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: WILL YOU PLEASE... please listen to me ... (HE GRABS PARRY by the shoulders) You know none of this is true - the Grail, the voices...                           Jack.. There's a part of you that                         Come o knows this isn't true.                             saying I know who you are...                              I know or who you were.                                   You're You don't belong on the                            No, no streets. You're intelligent                        Jack.. man....you're a teacher...                         Jacck! You were a teach at Hunter College. Don't you remember?...                               (SCR PARRY breaks away from him. HE falls back onto the ground THE SCREAM STOPS and is replaced by an eerie SILENCE. As if sound were ripped out of space. JACK speaks but no sound comes out...We are in PARRY'S world for this brief moment...JACK leans over to help PARRY, but the latter in away...fearful of the vision he sees: something out of si looming over JACK, breathing FIERY SMOKE...JACK tries to PARRY off the ground and, in doing so, the vision for PAR comes into full view:

dialogues.speaker: A MAGNIFICENT BURNISHED RED STEED
dialogues.text: stared down at Parry. On top of him sits the Red Knight. - a helmeted figure with a beard in a flowing red cap, holding a lance. He stares at Parry. Closing his eyes, Parry raises his hands to protect himself. Jack looks around and sees nothing. He acts with great co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mouthing in silence) Perry...you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE embraces PARRY by the shoulders. PARRY turns to him op his eyes, then turns back to the KNIGHT to discover that: The HORSE and the KNIGHT have moved several feet away, an are continuing to back up...as if in retreat. JACK speaks as the sound is returned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry answer me...are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY smiles in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows who you are! (amazed) He's afraid!  I can tell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're totally gone, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: THE RED KNIGHT
dialogues.text: He pulls the reins back, forcing the horse up onto its hind legs.  Then, he gallops off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got'em... come on!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry runs O.S. in the direction of the Knight.  Jack is not about to follow, until he sees -- Parry runs right into the intersection of 94th & Fifth almost getting hit hit by a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry reaches where the Red Knight stood and looks.

dialogues.speaker: THE RED KNIGHT
dialogues.text: riding onto the sidewalk and into Central Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY, as JACK reaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going o-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he can finish, PARRY is off again. JACK races afte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY climb the wall and run into the park. THEY dodge pas with strollers, runners, bikers, sun worshippers, etc.... THEY run deep into an extremely woody section of Central The RED KNIGHT appears first to the left, then re-appears the right. PARRY darts about like a madman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Red Knight is perched atop a rock. He and Parry excha looks. The Knight and his horse rear up, two towering fig against the Central Park South skyline. EXT. CENTRAL PARK - DAY. Parry, uttering a war cry, rushes off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, exhausted and bedraggled, climbs the rock to follow He reaches the top, panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...Oh...Oh God...I'm dying. I can't breath and I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE finds PARRY sitting Buddha-like, on the top of the roc calmly gazing out at the beautiful scenery before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it great up here... He's gone now, but we had him on the run! We would've had his ass if we had horses! He's running scared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHO! WHO'S RUNNING?!! WHO HAVE WE BEEN CHASING!?? CAN I ASK THIS QUESTION NOW!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS BACK SLOWLY from behind Jack and Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Jack. I thought you saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA reveals the head of a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAW WHO!!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Red Knight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Red...? (stares at him in wonder) You're totally gone, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrated, JACK turns to leave but this time there is a someone is crying O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .....Do you hear that?! Oh "Heaven be praised, in giving me an opportunity, so soon of fulfilling the duties of my profession...These cries doubtless proceed from some miserable male or female, who stands in need of my immediate aid and protection"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's off....A reluctant JACK pauses before following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The park's bridle path.  A BEATEN MAN cries as he sits in middle of the dirt bridle path - mumbling to himself, try to bury himself in dirt....HE hears the two men coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET AWAY! GET AWAY!!....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY kneels down to him. JACK keeps a safe distance away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's O.K...It's O.K...Lets me help you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO...I WANNA GO! I WANNA GO NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now...You can't sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! I want a debutante on a horse to step on me.  Leave me alone!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wanting to leave) Parry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, the days of the debutantes are ... not what they used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to cry) Isn't that awful? Poor Brenda Frazier. Poor Little Gloria. They ruined them! THEY ATE THEM ALIVE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping him up) It was a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone...I wanna go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY lifts him up - he looks to JACK for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get the other side. (JACK hesitates) Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's cuts and suicidal demeanor turn JACK off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, he just needs to sleep it off. Someone will take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he wants to stay here. (to bum) Do...do you want to stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly lucid and pissy) Oh, yes, thank you - I really love bleeding in horseshit. How very Gandhiesque of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY looks to JACK, who then begrudgingly helps the BUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a room at the end of the line of chairs, PARRY stands the GAY BUM. JACK stands a safe distance away, unable to take his eyes off the scene before him : seated against t wall are an assortment of derelicts, drunks, screaming wi victims and jacketed schizophrenics. JACK has a hard time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JACK, referring to GAY BUM) Will you watch him for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Jack can respond, PARRY shifts the GAY BUM'S body into JACK'S arms, then moves about the room, introducing himself to the various patients as JACK watches. HE moves down the line...saying hello, wiping people's brows, holding the hands of an angry bag lady mumbling incoheren Smiling and saying hello to each one, no matter how frigh they seem.  HE appears to have a soothing affect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna go...Just let me go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...Where...where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) A real nice place I know... Ah...can't get there! Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (being positive) Where?  Maybe we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, crying) No...no...we can't...we can't..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with more feeling) Come on...maybe we can...where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venice...Like Katherine Hepburn in SUMMERTIME. (The GAY BUM cries in frustration). ....Why can't I be Katherine Hepburn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stares at him, at a complete loss for a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna die...I just wanna die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, against all better judgement, pats the BUM'S hand i comfort. Unexpectedly, the GAY BUM leans his head on JACK shoulder, and cries. JACK, wide-eyed with embarassment, l over to PARRY -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY is teaching a song to a SCITZHO, A YUPPIE IN A STRA JACKET, and a paranoid BAG LADY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K..everyone know their parts... Here we go... (sings) "I like New York in June"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE points to the YUPPIE who replies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "How about you..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I like a Gershwin tune..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY points to the SCITZHO, who stares at him blankly, d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Good!.... "I like to read good books"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE points to the BAG LADY, who is talking to herself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell am I gonna put the children? Goddamn daughter-in-law! Comes into my house looking for dustballs! GET THE FUCK OUTTA MY DINING ROOM...you ingrate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tempo, people...tempo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, his arm around the despairing GAY MAN, is sharing h problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell me something? Did you lose your mind all of a sudden or was it a slow gradual process?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly coherent) Well,... I'm a singer by trade... Summer stock...nightclub revues... that kind of thing...It used to be what I absolutely lived for...God...I can do GYPSY backwards - every part- but, one night...in the middle of singing "Funny..... - it suddenly hit me... ...what does all of this really mean? (JACK nods in a knowing metaphysical aggreement) That, and the fact that all my friends are dead...God, I sound like a veteran. Dad would be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment a PIZZA BOY enters, making a delivery:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, DOCTORS and NURSES appear out of the wood work swarm around the delivery boy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMERGENCY ROOM- DAY
dialogues.text: PARRY notices the time, passing by the doctors and pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, it's almost five.  We're going to be late. We're going to miss her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY exits. JACK turns to the GAY BUM, exhaustedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...I've got to run. I've bee doing this all day.  Are you going to be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please!...I was born a Catholic in Brooklyn... I've been to hell and back.... I'll be fine... (adds quite sincerely:) ....Thanks...You're a gem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK nods, a little self-consciously, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY and JACK sit on the floor enjoying a cup of coffee. A VIETNAM VET in a wheelchair with no legs sits near the wall, along with at least fifteen other homeless beggers. Another MAN sits against a cash machine, crying. A WOMAN by and drops some change in the VET's cup without saying a word. The Vet, SID, smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God Bless You... Have a nice day. (to Jack and Parry) Ya hear Jimmy Nickels got picked up yesterday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry is too busy scanning the Grand Central main floor to answer.  Realizing Parry isn't answering, Jack feels obliged to pick up the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got caught -- (passer-by drops coins in cup) God bless... Have a safe trip home... (to Jack) -- Got caught pissin' on the bookstore.  Man's a pig.  No excuse for that.  We're heading for social anarchy when people start pissing on bookstores!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack smiles at this observation.  He then tries to get Parry's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never see her in this crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry doesn't answer.  He looks like a dog waiting for its master.  People walk by Jack at a frantic pace.  He sits uncomfortably against a wall.  A man almost steps on him as he walks by and tosses a coin at Sid, missing the cup and forcing Sid to bend over... Jack picks the coin up for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole!  Guy didn't even look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes coin) He's paying so he don't have to look. What he doesn't know is, he's paying for a service.  Guy goes to work every day and for eight hours, seven days a week, he bends over and gets it right up the ass till he can't stand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry stands up and begins pacing before the main floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... But one day, right before quitting time on Friday, his boss is going say something like "Say Bob -- come into my office and kiss my ass"... and Bob is going think -- "The hell with it!  I don't care what happens.  All I want right now is to see the expression on his face when I stab him with these pair of scissors"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry looks at the clock above the information booth -- 5:00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... But then he thinks of me -- "wait a minute!"... he says... "It's not so bad.  At least I got two arms and two legs and I ain't beggin' for money." He puts down the scissors, and puckers up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is impressed with this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... I'm what you call a moral traffic light.  It's like I'm saying "Red -- go no further."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. a black woman begins to sing.  Jack and Sid look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiles with respect) Ah, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET, a black woman in a paisley kaften, stands near a photo lab across from Jack and Sid.  With a box in front of her for donations, she starts singing (SONG to be chosen).  Some rush hour commuters stop to listen. Her VOICE is strong and soulful, she performs uninhibitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to admit though... Like at 5:00 in Grand Central... Pretty breathtaking, don't cha think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks around this mad rush hour scene, taking it in through Sid's eyes... Parry, however, keeps his gaze on the main floor.  Suddenly, he spots her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hordes of people are moving in every which way, zigzagging across the floor... Lydia moves through the crowd, avoiding touching anyone...

dialogues.speaker: PARRY
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS IN SLOWLY as we hear Margaret's SONG O.S. The closer the CAMERA gets to Parry the more her song changes... At first a blend of two melodies that sound distruptive, cachophonous... But as Parry smiles with joy, HIS SONG overtakes Margaret's... It is a WALTZ.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN FLOOR
dialogues.text: The hordes of people continue their zigzagging for a beat then: Suddenly, they pair up and waltz around the main floor, circling around the center information booth... Only Lydia remains walking -- gliding through the dancers with grace and ease... Parry watches in a state of rapture -- moving as she moves to keep her in eye view as long as possible.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: listening to Margaret's SONG, taking in the scene around him... watching people listen to her song, while others walk by as if they were deaf and blind... Feeling strangely at ease, strangely apart of everyone around him -- a group of lost souls listening to a woman bare her soul in song.  He looks to spot Parry, rises and crosses to him...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN FLOOR
dialogues.text: Parry watches as Lydia exits the main floor (the waltz has ended) just as Jack speaks his line:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a great song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to his own song) It's a classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks in the direction of Parry's stare and sees Lydia exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) God.  Just one night with her.  I'd die happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hears this as if a light bulb went off above his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens.  Lydia enters with a bag of groceries she picked up on the way.  She turns on the light to reveal an extremely neat, albiet modest, one bedroom apartment. She carries the grocery bag into the kitchen. Out of the bag, she removes a Lean Cuisine, a giant bottle of cream soda and four giant bars of Chunky chocolate.  She pops the Lean Cuisine into the oven and walks back into the living room to an old stereo.  She turns the TURNTABLE on -- a record already set upon it. She stands by her coffee table, as if taking position: Suddenly, we hear ETHEL MERMAN -- as Lydia lip-syncs every word with complete commitment -- giving a full out performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got no sunshine, got no rain Still I think I'm a lucky dame I got the sun in the morning And the moon at night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her attempts at hand gestures and choreography are awkward -- bunking into the coffee table, banging her hand against a lamp -- but, we see a part of Lydia that few (actually no one) sees.  Her abandon, her joy... her smile.  From upstairs, neighbors BANG for her to keep the music down.  Lydia casually crosses to the stereo, turns off the turntable and heads back to the kitchen -- as if the neighbors interference were all apart of her nightly ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits alone at her formica table, smoking a cigarette.  Two plates are set.  She waits for Jack.  She is hurt and pissed off.  TONY ORLANDO AND DAWN play on her stereo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock three times... on the ceiling if you want me... Twice on the pipes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song continues as the CAMERA SLOWLY PANS up to CLOSEUP of Anne, who is fighting with an imaginary Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya fuckin' bastard.  I don't need this... (emphasizing) ... I Do Not Need This!  A woman my age... I am a person.  This is kid stuff.  You come!  You go!  And all I do is cook like a jerk!  You're a waste of good cutlets... I don't need this... Find yourself another dope... ya fuckin' bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puffs on her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE walks deeper into the open field.  This makes JACK ner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's time to go now? Running around here during the day is one thing but at night we could be killed by a wide variety of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's stupid. This is my park just as much as it is theirs. You think it's fair they keep us out just because they make us think we'll get killed or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think that's very fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY takes off his pants and stands there naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) .....What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever done any cloudbusting? You lie on your back and you concentrate on the clouds...and you try yo break them apart with your mind. It's wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry lies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do this! This is New York! Nobody lies in naked in a field in New York..It's...it's too Midwestern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, try it. Ya feel the air on your body - ya little fella's flappin' in the breeze. ...everybody in the city is busy with their business and no one knows we're bare assed in the middle of it. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! I will not! This is nuts! I'm leaving! I mean it...this is nuts. (freaked, walking OC) This is too nuts...I'm leaving. I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK starts walking away from PARRY, talking to himself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..Ha...Little fella? I mean the man talks to invisible people - he sees invisible horses - and he's naked in the middle of Central Park. I should be surprised? I'm not surprised. I'm fucking outta my mind to even be here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back and yells) YOU'RE OUT OF YOUR FUCKING MIND!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE walks O.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK, fully clothed, lies next to PARRY looking up at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY stare up. JACK raises his head. HE unbuttons his shi maybe that will help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if some homophobic jogger runs by and kills us to get back at his overbearing father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry remains focused on the sky - in his own world. Something about cloudbusting makes Parry behave in a way seen before...He is un characteristically quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "JACK LUCAS FOUND DEAD - BESIDE A DEAD NAKED MAN...THE TWO WERE DEAD...HIS COMPANION WAS NAKED"...I hate when they use the word companion...It's so insinuating..Although, it'll probably boost my biography sales. The public loves stories about successful people falling into degenerate behavior. Makes them feel lucky to be boring and ordinary...People stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry suddenly speaks - as if talking to a lecture hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's begin with the story itself. It's a story of the Grail myth...And although there are several variations, my favorite begins with the Fisher King as a young boy... who had to spend a night alone in the forest to prove his courage... and during that night, he is visited by a sacred vision. Out of the fire, appears the Holy Grail - God's highest symbol of divine grace. And a voice says to the boy, "You shall be the guardian of the Grail, that it may heal the hearts of men"...But the boy was overcome ...Innocent and foolish, he was blinded by greater visions - a life ahead filled with beauty and glory, hope and power...Tears filled his eyes as he sensed his own... invincibility. A boy's tears of naive wonder and inspiration. and in this state of...radical amazement...he felt for a brief moment, not like a boy, but like God... (Jack listens intently) ...And so he reached into the fire to take the Grail. And the Grail vanished. And the boy hands were left caught in the flames...leaving him wounded and ashamed at what his recklessness had lost him. When he became King, he was determined to reclaim his destiny and find the Grail... But with each year that passed, with each campaign he fought, the Grail remained lost, and this wound he suffered in the fire grew worse... He became a bitter man. Life for him lost it's reason. With each disappointment, with each betrayal... with each loss ... this wound would grow... Soon the land began to spoil from neglect and his people starved...Until finally, the King lost all faith in God's existance and in man's value...He lost his ability to love or be loved And he was so sick with experience... that he started to die. As the years went on, his bravest knights would search for the Grail that would heal their King and make them the most respected and valued men in the land, but to no avail.  Pretty soon, finding the Grail became a ruthless struggle between ambitious men vying for the King's power, which only confirmed the King's worst suspicions of man, causing his wound to grow. His only hope, he thought, was death. Then one day, a fool was brought in to the King to cheer him.  He was a simple-minded man... not particularly skilled...or admired... He tells the King some jokes...sing him some songs, but the King feels even worse...Finally, the fool says, "What is it that hurts you so much? How can I help?"...And the King says, "I need a sip of water to cool my throat"...So, the fool takes a cup from the bedstand, fills it with water and hands it to the King...Suddenly, the King feels a lot better. And when he looks to his hands, he sees that it was the Holy Grail the fool handed him...an ordinary cup that had been beside his bed all along...And the King asks, "How can this be?...how could you find what all my knights and wisest men could not find"? And the fool answers, "I don't know. I only knew you were thirsty."... And for the first time since he was a boy, the King felt more than a man - not because he was touched by God's glory...but rather, by the compassion of a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK doesn't know how to respond. HE's never known PARRY be eloquent. HE gets a glimpse of PARRY as he once was an the words come out of his mouth before he knows it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But PARRY seems far away. HE speaks like a professor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fisher King myth has alot of derivations...I remember I was at this lecture in Princeton once - and there was this one speaker...Henry Sa... Henry...uh...Henry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE stops. As if this memory escaped with any warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ....What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is as surprised as he is. PARRY'S face is frightened and confused again. There is panic in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ....What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE raises his head to look and sees: EXT. SHEEPS MEADOW: SEVERAL YARDS AWAY - NIGHT. THE DARK SILOUETTE OF THE RED KNIGHT UPON HIS HORSE. Star knowing exactly where PARRY lies even though it's dark. PARRY looks frightened as he lays his head back down. JACK tries to snap him out of it by saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you've never asked that girl for a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARRY looks back to see that the RED KNIGHT has vanished. HE snaps out of it somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't ask for her...I have to earn her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry, you don't have to earn a woman. It's the twentieth century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, when we get the Grail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, see, I think she can help...You know women are great..they...they make homes and they..ya know, kill the livestock so the knights can go out and get Grails and...and slaughter villages with a clear head...I mean, where would Arthur be without Guinevere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happily married, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad example. Just trust me. A woman who loves you keeps you going...gives you strength... Makes you feel like you can do anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what your girlfriend does for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then lies:) Sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK waits near the elevators as the nine-to-five crowd m their way into the building.  HE looks like a bum - havin stayed out all night with PARRY....HE'S so tired he can't keep  his  eyes  opened  as  LYDIA walks  with  the  crow to the elevator... Just as the doors close, JACK spots he and jumps in between them - causing the inhabitants a jol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open. LYDIA gets off after two leggy businesswomen. JACK follows. SHE walks through two glass doors with the words TWO HEARTS PUBLISHING, INC. and ente the office. JACK waits until she had disappeared down a foyer, then enters the reception area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you help me-- what was the name of that girl who just came in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What girl?  I didn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... she was wearing a kind of... a flouncy kind of... uh... plain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes big gestures with his arms to describe the dress, the stringy gestures with his fingers to describe her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winning at Charades) Oh, Lydia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia.  Lydia what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I have no idea.  She's worked here for fifteen years and I have no idea.  I'll call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no... that's all right... I thought I knew her... Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is on the phone, with an open Yellow Pages beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Two Hearts Publishing?  May I speak to Lydia please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits.  Anne enters.  She is obviously very irritated with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have my desk please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone) Hello, I'd like to speak to Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia?!  Lydia who!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anne) I don't know her last name... I'll be off in a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're calling Lydia in my office. You must think I'm some dope.  You fuckin' bastard... You... (she punches his arm) ... stay out all night long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, to phone) What... No... Lydia... I want to speak to... her name is Lydia... I...uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) ... I don't get a friggin' phone call.  You stroll in here at noon.  I got... two people out sick.  Ya think I need this?  I Do Not Need This!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Forget it... Goodbye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Anne sits down at her desk.  She is waiting for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not with a woman last night.  I was out with Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is the girl Parry likes... And I thought, if I could get them together I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  The curse'll be lifted?  Will you please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... You're not going to understand this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't treat me like I'm stupid.  It pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... Sorry... I feel indebted to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I told you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought... if... if I can help him in some way... you know?... get him this girl he loves... Then... maybe.... things'll start changing for me... My luck, ya know... Maybe... (gives up) Forget it... It's a stupid idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks at him incredulously.  He sits down and breathes a sigh -- the absurdity of the idea hitting him as well.  Anne softens -- feeling like she has unfairly taken the wind out of his sail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you poor kid... You're a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne stands and buries Jack's face in her breast.  She decides to be positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Well, listen... stranger things have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack on the phone to Lydia.  This time Anne is right beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abrasively) Yeah?  Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her abrupt manner surprises Jack.  Jack uses his old, confident radio voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jack Lucas and I'm calling from Video Pop video rentals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes well... (guessing and hoping) You are a credit card holder, are you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations Lydia, because out of several thousand card holders... in conjunction with several major credit card companies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them... Which means you have just won a free membership at our store on Second Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the reciever near a tape player and presses play. "HAPPY DAYS ARE HERE AGAIN" plays for a moment, then he shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan, not getting it) How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is prepared for Lydia's, shall we say, reluctance to buy it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name was picked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious... and dense) Well, I don't understand.  What did you do -- did you pick my name out of a hat or... or... a list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- were there a lot of people in the room or just you or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to answer) Well there.... (then) What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean... I don't know you... This has never... I've never won anything and... I don't have a VCR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get a VCR with the membership. (ANNE hits him) ... For a short time until you get your own.  Listen, why don't you come down to the store and you can check it out.  See if you're interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Phyllis in accounting tell you to call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fed up) No!  I told you! You won a contest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia hangs up.  Jack turns to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ....This is going to be rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK stands beside a costumed GAY BUM in a crowded elevat The Bum warms up to the elevator's muzak. JACK shoves him A somber looking BUSINESSMAN rides along side, reading a newspaper. The GAY BUM moves next to him and looks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Anne Morrow Lindbergh and I can't find my baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUSINESSMAN is stunned...HE laughs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I knew I could make you smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open. JACK stands beside THE GAY BUM w carries balloons marked VIDEO SPOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamant) Remember. One chorus and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a man with a mission, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GAY BUM walks to the office entrance. JACK pushes the button. As the doors close, we hear him say to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm on a first name basis with these people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GAY BUM enters the reception area, much to the surpri the receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ... help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a mousy woman who works here named Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes..if you'll wait here I'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a personalized message. I have to give it in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GAY BUM strolls nonchalantly into the office and down relishing in the amazed expressions of the employees. HE a cubicle on which he reads a small name plate - LYDIA SI LYDIA has her back to him, but slowly turns as she feels watching her. SHE lets out a tiny scream when she sees hi standing there like a deranged clown. The GAY BUM take no her outfit - a cordoroy, forest green jumper with a lime green turtleneck -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You MUST be SHE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GAY BUM begins to sing a SONG PARODY to the tune of a classical musical number. (Song to be chosen). After a bi the GAY BUM hands LYDIA a business card, drops the act an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs cynically) Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, LYDIA looks down at the information card she hol frozen in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. on ANNE, who is slighted repulsed by PARRY. JACK PARRY; his hair slicked back, wearing a Video Spot T over his clothes. Jack hangs a car pine freshner around P neck to help with the smell...The bell on front door jing LYDIA cautiously enters the store. Behind the counter, JACK spots her immediately and nudges SHE turns to look, her bra straps are visible. JACK fixes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Lydia Sinclair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Hi..Congratulations. Jack Lucas. Nice to meet you finally. This is Anne Napolitano, the owner of Video Spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello....congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is our other..uh...co-worker.. Parry..uh...Parry....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry Parry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No just Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...like Moses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows how to respond to this, so they don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; curt) So how do we do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well..um...you get an official membership card... (takes one out) Just sign that and we'll laminate it right here... Parry?  You want to laminate Miss Sinclair's card?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry stands staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...Parry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry snaps out of it and crosses from behind the counter to the laminating machine next to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will last you one year after which you have the option to renew if... you like at a membership discount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) But now it's free, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne backs off.  She stands next to an equally perplexed Jack as they watch Lydia fill out the card.  Her abrasive demeanor is not what they expected.  Lydia finishes the card and pushes it toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... you... you can pick out up to ten movies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  They're free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (butts in) Only the first ten.  After that they're 2.99 a rental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia eyes Anne suspiciously, then turns to survey the shelves.  Parry picks up her card and laminates it -- all the while, keeping his eyes fixed upon Lydia's every move.  Anne and Jack, having set the trap, watch with interest. Lydia surveys the film boxes, H-L.  She spots one of interest and pulls it off the shelf -- causing two other boxes to fall down on her.  She catches one box and, as she replaces it back on the shelf, causes three more to fall.  She catches two of the three. Parry, Anne and Jack watching with an odd fascination. Jack nudges Parry to forget the laminating and go help her.  Parry gathers up his nerve and moves from around the counter, up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Can... can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia quickly turns -- she is uncomfortable by his closeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No... I can look myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away abruptly -- like a fox terrier who pretends to ignore the mess she made on the living room rug. Parry turns to Jack and Anne, as if to say "what do I do now?"  Jack encourages him to keep trying.  Parry organizes the boxes and picks one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the "Hell Merchants"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like horror movies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) How about... Zbiegnew Speizak's "The Purple Bread," an intensely portrayed tale of love and envy set against the sweeping background of a Polish bakery.  In subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like... uh... (finding it hard to categorize) Polish love stories... (she turns her back on him, but adds) ... I like musicals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encouraged) Well, we have plenty of those.  Right over here.  We got the MGM series, Astaire and Rogers, the Judy Garlands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any Ethel Merman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't see any.  He looks to Anne, who shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Uh... we seem to be all out of Ethel Merman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a gyp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack nudges Anne to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think I... ordered some just the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well did you or didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed off) Yes!  They'll be in soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll come back then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia walks back to the counter.  As Jack hands her the card, she notices Anne's painted star fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your nails.  Where did you get them done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... I do them myself.  I used to work in a beauty parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia keeps staring at them.  She says blankly;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Anne does other people too. Sort of a sideline... (Anne is surprised to hear this. ... If you want, she could do your nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since you're a member, we could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia considers the offer.  Parry waits for the outcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... twenty dollars... When can you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight!  How's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia thinks.  Anne is ready to kill Jack.  Parry smiles hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack searches frantically through a closet.  Anne and Parry sit opposite each other at the table.  Parry is eating Anne's homecooking voraciously.  Anne doesn't quite know how to take Parry, who smiles mischieviously through his meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack O.S.) Getting your nails done is one thing but going to dinner with a bunch of strangers and him... She didn't even look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any more bread crust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anne resentfully rises and crosses into the kitchen, Parry focuses on her robust breasts bouncing beneath the sweater.  Anne's expression, as she serves him, is a mixture of repulsion and fascination... She sits at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make it very casual... not like  a date or anything.  I just have to find something he'll look good in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks at Parry as if this were an impossibility. Parry smiles back -- he likes Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... He's a little disgusting... Although some women go for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just needs some clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any more starchy food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another opportunity to watch Anne's breasts in action, as she reluctantly rises to get him more macaroni.  She returns with the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I've gone out with bums, but they were gorgeous.  It's the only reason to go out with a bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This food's delicious.  You're a wonderful cook.  And you have a lovely home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, he's starting a conversation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well talk back.  He won't bite you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool and polite) Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying the conversation) Your welcome.  You know, a beautiful woman like yourself -- your own business -- I'm surprised some guy doesn't snatch you up for his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks in Jack's direction, but replies to Parry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're surprised!... But I guess I just never met the right guy.  Whatta gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shocked.  With a child bearing body like yours... (Anne doesn't know how to take that) ... why a man would have to be out of his mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most men are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why this is outrageous!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry, getting overly heated, slams down his fork.  Anne jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... A woman of your value going to waste before my eyes.... (rising intensity) Come on!  I'm yours!  Let's go! (clears the table with one move) Come on -- let us go to that place of splendor in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to unzip his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climbing over the table to her, he seranades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holdin' my penis... What a lovely way of sayin' how Much ya like me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, out of your mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holdin' my penis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry!  Close your pants...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parry stops singing and gets off the table.  He bows to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding) You sure now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks at him like she's going to belt him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Well alright.  But you let me know. (with great sincerity) You're too good a woman to go to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, in spite of herself, agrees with him.  She looks to Jack to see if he agrees, but Jack is too busy inspecting Parry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you -- a 40 in a jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, frustrated with the two of them, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia walks up and RINGS the bell.  BUZZED in -- she enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne's opens the door to a cautious Lydia.  Lydia nods, self-consiously, as if to say, "Yeah, I'm here".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... welcome... Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia enters, subtly inspecting the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been in an apartment above a store.  You always pass them on the street but you never think anyone really lives in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising an eyebrow) Can I get you anything...coffee... tea...a little tequilla?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYDIA sits at the formica table, already set up with nail paraphernalia - with the gleaming steel nail files it loo bit like surgery equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly) That all depends on you. ...Sure you don't want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYDIA's a little nervous about this attempt at nail beaut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is cleaning up Parry - perhaps applying a green mud treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE is seated at her formica table opposite LYDIA. SHE delicately holds one of LYDIA'S hands, carefully applying stars to her nails. LYDIA sips her tequilla with one hand ANNE'S glass is almost empty as she talks non-stop;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So he says to me, "you'll never find another man like me"...I said, "please, men like you have one hand on their dicks and the other hand on their mother's leg... I said, there's the door - take a trip.

dialogues.text: (paying close attention) You threw him out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE makes a confident nod. LYDIA sips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents were divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an awful thing, let me tell you. My Aunt used to say, (emphasizing) "divorce is the sister-in-law of death".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE nods knowingly. LYDIA squints as she considers this.

PARRY squeezes a ball of mousse in his h then applies it to his head....PARRY proceeds to experime with a number of styles - adding more and more mousse as watches in silence. PARRY molds his hair into a cone, the divides into two cones, then mushes it into a pompadour, splits the pompadour - PARRY is having a wonderful time - applying enormous amounts to his head and eyebrows....Fin JACK grabs the can out of PARRY'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) Do I look like I have someone special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE moves to picks up her tequilla with the manicured han ANNE eyes her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't say it like that. It's not so...ya know, crazy an idea. You are a healthy woman... You hold a steady job. Ya not crossed eyed or anything...
